name: Introduction The topics covered in this book include

description: Tidal pools, stream mouths, or stand- protected by sandy barrier islands. ing seawater trapped behind a sandbar at low tide can be Bog, deep 10% found on many beaches. A pool or stream has shallow Bog, shallow 20% water about 1 foot in depth. It costs 2 squares of movement Creek 10% to enter a pool or stream, and the DC of Tumble checks Mud flat 10% increases by 2. Open water 20% Reeds 30% Tidal pools are normally 1d4×5 feet wide. Streams or bar-trapped ponds are the same width, but can be hundreds of feet long. Bog: Tidal marsh bogs are more accurately called
name: Pool or Stream

description: Pebble beaches are similar to areas of light sloughs, wallows, or ponds, but they are otherwise identical rubble (see page 91 of the Dungeon Master’s Guide). The DC to the bog squares described on page 88 of the Dungeon of Balance and Tumble checks increases by 2. Master’s Guide. 16 1 RETPAHC EHT OTNI MORTSLEAM
name: Rubble

description: A creek has the same effect as a deep bog (see Marsh Terrain, page 88 of the Dungeon Master’s Guide), but it is normally 1d8 squares wide and meanders across the battlefi eld.
name: Creek

description: A mud fl at consists of bare, more or less solid ground. It costs 2 squares of movement to enter a square of mud fl at.
name: Mud Flat

description: Large pitches of open wa- ter interspersed with wet, grassy land make up much of a tidal marsh. Open water is sim- ply water ranging from 5 to 20 feet in depth; it tends to be shallower near land.
name: Open Water

description: Stands of tall reeds can be found in shallow water or on land. A stand of reeds offers concealment to anyone who ventures 5 feet into the reeds, and total concealment to any- one who has 10 feet or more of reeds between them and the viewer. It costs 2 squares of movement to enter a square of reeds, and the DC of Tumble checks in such a square increases by 2. A stand of reeds is normally 1d8 squares wide.
name: Reeds

description: Tidal marshes tend to be fl at and open; the max- imum distance at which a Spot check to detect the nearby presence of others can succeed is 6d6×20 feet. However, you’re usually not more than a few squares away from a creek, slough, or stand of reeds to hide in, if you don’t mind getting wet and muddy. CORAL REEF Warm seas are renowned for their beautiful coral reefs. Encounters in coral reefs can be on the surface (characters can walk or wade on those portions of the reef that are awash, or submerged by not more than a few feet of A reef encounter water) or under the water (the characters and their adversaries are swimming). In general, submerged coral reefs occupy water that is Submerged Surface Coral, dead 20% 30% 1d8×10 feet in depth, and the coral itself is 1d4×10 feet in Coral, living 30% — height (but does not rise above the surface in any event, Coral, shallow 20% 30% since this will kill the animals whose shells make up the Pass 10% 10% reef). Deepwater corals, though rare, can be found 200 or Pothole — 5% Sandy bottom 20% 10% more feet down. A distinct reef or coral head is a steep- Surf, heavy — 5% sided underwater boulder, hillock, or plateau anywhere Surf, light — 10% from a few squares across to miles in extent. Coral reefs that reach the surface (or close to it) occupy Coral, Dead: Near or on the surface, dead coral is gener- water that is 1d2×10 feet in depth, and the reef masses or ally smoother and easier to walk across than living coral. coral heads are the same height—although deep channels, It costs 2 squares of movement to enter a square of dead potholes, or the edge of the reef offer plenty of opportuni- coral, and the DC of Balance and Tumble checks increases ties to get into deep water. by 4. samohT .J yb .sullI 17 MAELSTROM INTO THE CHAPTER 1

A pothole thinner (and more dangerous) of the two, with large is typically 5 to 10 feet deep. Entering a pothole square stretches of open water. Pack ice is much thicker. Spot check to notice the pothole before stepping into it. description: Ships and boats of Gargantuan size or MARINE larger normally have heavy hulls. Heavy hulls consist of DUNGEON TERRAIN sturdy, waterproofed planks backed by more planks, fixed Ship interiors, sea-floor dungeons or ruins, and water-filled to a reinforced strong skeleton of timbers. Hulls offer few chambers in more conventional adventure sites often handholds for climbers (Climb DC 25). feature specific types of walls, floors, or other dungeon Hull, Light: Most ships and boats of Huge size or dressings. In addition to the special materials and features smaller have light hulls. Light hulls consist of sturdy, described here, simple hewn or dressed stone walls and waterproofed planks fixed to a strong skeleton or frame- floors are every bit as commonplace in watery chambers work of shaped timbers. Like heavy hulls, light hulls offer as they are in dry ones. few handholds for climbers (Climb DC 25).

description: The difficulty of setting an accurate You can check for encounters once per hour of travel course depends on the quality of information you have (good for short voyages) or once per day of travel (good about where you’re going. See Knowledge (geography) in for longer voyages). The chance per day is simply the Chapter 4 for a list of DCs and modifiers for course setting. cumulative chance of having at least one encounter, based The DM makes this check for you, since you don’t know on the hourly encounter chances—use one or the other, for certain if you have planned an accurate course. but not both. If you don’t have any particular destination in mind, you don’t need to set a course.
